reasoning: The critique targets a sub-claim implicit in some examples (especially Sec. 2.3.4): that alternative allocation regimes are “selectable” without being endogenously reshaped by incentives. If correct, this would weaken those illustrative examples and suggest the paper under-models strategic dynamics. However, it is not very central to the paper’s main thesis (“no easy eutopia” / eutopian fragility), because (i) the paper’s core argument is that near-best futures are a narrow target due to many possible value-destroying dimensions, and strategic gaming generally makes that target narrower rather than broader; and (ii) the paper does not rely on the catastrophes being accidental rather than equilibrium outcomes. The critique’s strength is moderate: it raises a real governance/equilibrium-design issue, but it overstates the extent to which the paper treats these as simple ‘moral dials’ (the essay already gestures at politics, power, and motivated reasoning), and it doesn’t show that the paper’s conclusion is undermined. Relevance is fairly high because incentive-compatibility, power concentration, and space-resource governance are live, decision-relevant topics in Forethought’s Tier 2–3 agenda. Overall, it’s a useful corrective/extension to the examples, but it doesn’t substantially refute the central argument.
title: "Strategic optimisation undermines proposed allocation regimes"
